column1: The union of a royal title with priestly duties was common in ancient Italy and Greece. At Rome and in other cities of Latium there was a priest called the Sacrificial King or King of the Sacred Rites
column2: and his wife bore the title of Queen of the Sacred Rites. In republican Athens the second annual magistrate of the state was called the King
column3: and his wife the Queen; the functions of both were religious. Many other Greek democracies had titular kings
column5: so far as they are known
column7: and to have centered round the Common Hearth of the state. Some Greek states had several of these titular kings
column8: who held office simultaneously. At Rome the tradition was that the Sacrificial King had been appointed after the abolition of the monarchy in order to offer the sacrifices which before had been offered by the kings. A similar view as to the origin of the priestly kings appears to have prevailed in Greece.
